content:
{{knowledge objective
|Identifiant=OIC-336-11-B
|Item_parent=Non-traumaticoma in adults and children
|Item_parent_short=Non-traumatic coma in adults and children
|Rank=B
|Title=Modensitometry of intracranial haemorrhage
|Description=To recognise spontaneous intraparenchymal and subarachnoid hyperdensity (to be homogenised with item 341).
|Rubric=Multimedia content
|Contributors=Nicolas Weiss
|Order=11}}
'''Haemorrhagic stroke, intracerebral haematoma :'''<gallery widths="300" heights="300">
File:Haemorrhagic stroke 1.png
File:Haemorrhagic stroke 2.png
</gallery>- '''Spontaneous hyperdensity within the cerebral parenchyma'''

- Ventricular flooding possible

- Possible mass effect


'''Hémorragie méningée'''<gallery widths="300" perrow="300">
File:Meningeal haemorrhage.jpg
</gallery>- '''Spontaneous hyperdensity in the subarachnoid spaces'' (cisterns of the base, sulci, ...)

- Aneurysms are rarely visible without the injection of iodinated contrast (if calcified or large).

question.title: What is the term for spontaneous hyperdensity within the cerebral parenchyma?

option_a.title: Intraparenchymal hemorrhage
option_a.description: A type of bleeding within the brain tissue

option_b.title: Subarachnoid hemorrhage
option_b.description: A type of bleeding in the space surrounding the brain

option_d.title: Meningeal hemorrhage
option_d.description: A type of bleeding in the meninges, the protective membranes surrounding the brain

correct_option.title: A
correct_option.description: The correct letter of the answer
